- -'adau.definition: fond of, crazy about, favorite thing

examples.english: I'm fond of oranges, I just love oranges.
She's fond of rasp- berries, she just loves raspberries. [GT, MMc]

notes: The initial prefix on this word agrees with the initial prefix on the word naming the thing liked. The possessive prefix refers to the person who likes the thing named. For ex- ample: I-cha-'adau i-gunat "She's fond of salmon"

Clearly related to Warm Springs word átau. When the possessive prefix is a single consonant, there occurs with this word the sequence consonant+glottal stop, which other- wise is not known to occur in Wasco. (In Wasco, a glottal stop normally occurs either at the beginning of a word or between vowels, but not after another consonant.) Hence, it is almost certain that this word was borrowed from Warm Springs to Wasco rather than the other way around.

-k'ani.definition: white person [Dyk, SW 3/ 22/52, HS 7/27/54], non-Wasco, non-Nadidanwit [PK 6/29/56], story, legend, character (of person)

forms.english: story- story [formula for announcing the close of a legend] [WTI.11.17]

notes: The noun stem -k'ani has a variety of meanings. Its original meaning appears to have been "natu- ral way" or "story;" then it came to be used of white people through a process that is not entirely clear. When used with the prefix i- it usu- ally has the meaning "white man," but may also mean "story, legend" or "character (of a person)." When used with the prefix a-, it always now means "white woman." The forms itk'anyuksh and iłk'anyuks mean "white persons." Otherwise, when used with the prefix it-, it means "people's ways," usually "Indian ways" or "ancient (Indian) ways;" see it-k'ani. It also usually has that mean- ing when used with the initial prefix i- and the possessive prefix -ła- ("their"), to form iłak'ani; but iłak'ani may also refer to white people's ways.

Got a wife, go to this one, you go with her, she take au- thority on her pretty soon; she'll wait, take a chance something hap- pen to your wife; she'll step in. From -gug̲a 'go to accompany somebody (but not bring her in).' "Man has wife, old and sick—she say, 'Okay, you go to her; when I die, you bring her in.' Even before old woman dies; 'I'm gonna let her in here, even before I die; I'll just lie here my last days.' Legal in Wishram. "ił.ła.xa.g̲wamx: their —. When a man has a harem, like PK's grandfather; he took 3; or like Arabs. With Wishram, second wife is equal to first, 3rd same way; children all equal; my mother was bornin harem, others born in harem my cousins from same Silaetsi. All equal. All upperclass Wishrams anyway."

Though this word sounds like English "chimney," the -la- shows that it was borrowed from the French word la cheminé, almost certainly via Chinook Jargon. The French -ch- usually represents the "sh" sound, so the -ch- in this word may reflect English influence, or else a dialectical French pronunciation. Compare a- lashmni.

gayabaxem.definition: alligator [Dyk, PK], dragon of some kind [HS 7/25/56]
notes: Apparently used without prefix. According to a note in Dyk, this refers to "some fabulous monster [with the] appearance of an alligator; Phillip Kahclamat [says it is] now alligator." Hiram Smith [7/25/56] denied it referred to an alligator, but to some large monster no longer seen today. He also connected it with the particle bax, "charm, hoodoo." Ap- parently, this word referred to some sort of monster from legend times. Some people used it in modern times to refer to an alligator.

Borrowed from English.

Refers to the long white sacs in a male fish after they have been dried by fire. The undried sacs are it- tq'ín. Dyk gives both this form and itch'atqch'ataq for this meaning.

Coined by PK from dach'ip "striped" and ikíutan "horse." A few days earlier he had coined the word ich'ibumit for "zebra."

Refers to a monster in legend- times who dwelt in the river and swallowed people.
The same as i-g̲awulx. [GT 1/ 14/99] This word may have origi- nated as a respectful name, or a euphemism, for "rattlesnake;" it is clearly related to ich'lmax "greatgrandfather."

forms.english: 2 cat-tails [HS 7/21/52; in other words, HS maintained that ich'áxiu could be either singular or plural, but that there was a distinct form for the dual]

i-chag̲ulaimxat.definition: moving to a place where one can dig roots, pick berries, and hunt in the summer months

i-chak'íwalu.definition: end of winter (when food is all gone)

examples.kiksht: Dauya ikala idialálamax k'ma dnux (dnu, nux, nu) ixat ikala idiat'úlalamax.

Never- theless, just the same, he is growing. [Dyk]
a man and also a woman

notes: Apparently means about the same as mag̲a, which is almost cer- tainly a contracted form of it. A com- pound of k'ma and ag̲a.

examples.english: How is this! He's just like Coyote! [WTI.8.3]

examples.kiksht: Dauya ikala idialálamax k'manux ixat ikala idiat'ulálalmax.

notes: Meaning uncertain.

notes: Used with future tense to indicate a command or exhortation.

kadux.pronunciation: Varies between kadúx and kádux. In the sense "morning" it is usually kadúx.

examples.english: Go for a walk every day. [Spilyay/Healthy Nations]
I'll go fishing with a dip net while lots of Chinook salmon are running. [Dyk]

kanamdimaxix.definition: both sides of river, tree, lake, hole

because close to five I was walking in the place

examples.english: The people are hungry (literally 'hunger does them'). [WTI.13.8]

notes: Borrowed from English.

examples.english: He is in the habit, has the habit. [Dyk]

notes: Phillip Kahclamat on this word: "Take a horse, he'll do some- thing and get away with it; he knows he can do it and get away with it again. Do it once/get away with it; you'll do it again, get away with it." See PK's comment on i-kw'anmax.

examples.english: Hiram Smith did not believe this could be rendered in English. It is an expression of disgust, as 'Ah, those people!

Pfui on those people!' Connotations of 'let them do it themselves, I won't do it for them' in explanation by analogous situa- tion. (But this explanation seems to refer more to Coyote's motivation than to sense of word itself, or more to part {of the statement} after kw'anmax.)]

notes: A cry of warning.

he is too much, thinks too much of himself, is too proud

notes: Borrowed to or from Sahaptin kw'ałi "glad, happy."

examples.english: a new man, one just coming to manhood

'Let's go now.' 'After a while.' [Dyk] kwal [adv] quickly

again the same, the same again

the last of the bread, that's all the bread
I'm drinking the last bit of water. [GT 1/14/99]

I made myself light, I re- duced. [Dyk]

Literally "fourth day." This was suggested by Dell Hymes, follow- ing the pattern of makwshtba wigwa, which is found in Wishram Texts for "Tuesday."

Why don't you work at Berkeley? [Dyk]

examples.english: You'll go or I'll go, how about it?

examples.kiksht: Wax anłuxwa iłk'iwaxmat awachi kwaish, qengi ch'ala?

notes: Apparently a variety of jack salmon.
According to a note appar- ently by David French, this refers to any plant with a scratchy, prickly, or sticky quality. Compare cheqcheq "scratchy."

Originally referred to under- ground lodge, a winter dwelling dug partway into the ground. Now refers to a cellar. [Dyk] What is undoubt- edly the same word is spelled wachélx in Wishram Texts and so pronounced by Gladys Thompson and Madeline McInturff.

The difference in translation may be due to the fact that the Wasco month overlapped two Anglo months. PK 7/10/56 explained the name by saying that in this month people got angry at one another (because they had been confined in winter lodges for some time?) and spoke to one another over their shoulders, without turning around. Compare wachk'én "shoulder."

examples.english: I stuffed the deer with grass.
I stuffed grass in the deer.
In the morn- ing she fixed the hay.

notes: A 4 to 8 inch wooden needle for sewing tuli mats.

wa-ck'ún.definition: dipper [Dyk; PK 6/28/ 51; HS 7/21/56], tin cup [HS 7/21/ 56], cup [GT, MMc]
notes: This word probably referred originally to wooden dippers; in the course of time it has come to be a general word not only for dippers but also for cups, including tea and coffee cups. Hiram Smith, however, used a special expression for coffee or tea cup, given above.

examples.english: one piece of hail, one hailstone [HS 7/21/56]

notes: This appears to be a "talking small" form of a word *wa-chaqwsh, which however has not been found.
Not used with possessive prefixes; compare ish-g̲iłti.
Refers to a side of any fish but chinook salmon, with slits across from stakes. A side of chinook is i- sk'imks. A slice of dried salmon with- out slits is ił-katichk.
This word means steps that you go up, as to a porch. [GT, MMc 6/5/98]
seeAlso: ish-íxtksh, id-íxtksh, wa- ixtkísht, ish-ixtkist, id-ixtkíshtk

notes: Means the same as wa-ixtksh. [GT 6/5/98]
A ball used in games and gambling.
Refers to a baby before it walks or talks.
May refer either to reeds in a natural state or to a split reed used for a knife.

The translation and form of this word are uncertain. Dyk includes a note in square brackets below the first syllable of the word: [wfl]. This may mean that wa- is not a classify- ing prefix, but another element of unknown origin and function.

wa-kshti.definition: things poured over head of bride in wedding ceremony

examples.english: They (people on woman's side) pour trinkets over the head of the new bride. (which were then picked up by people on man's side) [GT, MMc 6/5/98]

notes: Gladys Thompson and Madeline McInturff see this as a spe- cial use of wakshti "bugs."

wa-kuch.definition: salmon backbone, fish backbone [Dyk, PK 9/2/55], chain links held together by bar [PK 9/2/ 55]
notes: According to PK, this refers to a piece of filleted salmon which in- cludes the backbone and tail with flesh adhering; or it can refer to a fish skeleton. It is not clear whether this refers solely to salmon or to fish backbones generally. GT 6/4/98 says this can refer to any fish backbone, but MMc seems to think it's just salmon. aksalk'uc is "backbone" gen- erally (for mammals, including hu- mans). See also i-kuch.
Refers to the constructed platform from which people fished.

forms.english: her hunger; she is one who always gets hungry
our repeated hunger; the hunger of each one of us

examples.english: She was hungry for acorns. See also: kush

wa-lxi.definition: dipnetting place [Dyk], place to catch animals [PK], fishing place along river belonging to famiy lineage [GT, MMc 6/4/98]

wa-lxiqsht.definition: water bug, louse found on owls and chickens

wa-lxiqst.definition: water bug, louse found on owls and chickens

wi-kít.definition: wedding [HS 7/26/56], giving things for a wife [HS 7/26/56, AF 8/19/53], bridal gift [Dyk], bride- price [WTII.1.1]
notes: Refers to the bridal gifts given by the groom to the bride's parents, who then distributed them among relatives.
Refers to a long narrow bay or indentation, not backwater.

examples.english: The Chinook salmon looked care- fully over all the land.
Ground, ground it made itself (as when after the snow melts, ground appears everywhere) [Dyk]
all along the river [Dyk's transcription: yaka we:mał] [Dyk]

examples.kiksht: G̲angadix galux̲wílaitix adasq'ú idelxam kana'amdmax̲ wimałba.

notes: Comment by Phillip Kahclamat: "Sapir said the Columbia is the only one called wimał, but I'd call the Amazon, Mississippi that." Apparently this word refers to large rivers. Compare wi-qał.
"They really burn when they get on you, have stickers on them." [GT 12/29/97]

forms.english: I notched around it[a-] on it[i-] (it[a-] being on it[i-] as a covering) [Dyk]

notes: From Chinook Jargon, which in turn borrowed the word from French les pois.
Most commonly a cry for help. Dyk labels it "a woman's word." See also: anáaa, aláaa

forms.english: I'm sick! I'm hurt! (used by children) [DykGr 141]

examples.english: Gee it's hot [used by older people]. [Dyk]

notes: A term used by old people or by children, or to children to warm them not to do something dangerous or naughty.
